publicationStmt.publisher: Anonymous (Tudor) () The Rare Triumphes of Loue and Fortune. Plaide before the Queenes most excellent Maiestie: wherin are manye fine Conceites with great delight London Printed by E. A. for Edward White [etc.] 1589

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
Love and fortune. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1589. Date first performed: 30 Dec 1582.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Iupiter. Tisiphone. Mercury. Vulcan. Venus. Fortune. Hermione. Fidelia. Armenio. Phizanties Duke. Penulo. Bomelio. Lentulo. Bomelio, Seriant
UNK

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div2.stage: Enter Mercury, then riseth a Furie: then enter the assembly of the Gods, Iupiter with Iuno, Apollo with Minerua, Mars and Saturne, after Uulcan with Uenus, the Fury sets debate amongst them, and after Iupiter speakes as followeth.

sp.speaker: Jupiter.
sp.p: Ye Gods and Goddesses, whence springs this strife of late? who are the authors of this mutiny? Or whence hath sprung this civil discord here: which on the sudden struck us in this fear. If Gods that reign in Skies do fall at war, No marvel then though mortal men do jar. But now I see the cause thou Fury fell, Bred in the dungeon of the deepest hell, Who causeth thee to show thy self in light, and what thy message is, I charge thee tell upright.

sp.speaker: Tisiphone.
sp.p:
O Jupiter thou dreadful king of Gods and men the father hie, to whose command the heavens, the earth and lowest hell obey: Tysiphone the daughter of eternal night, Bred in the bottom of the deepest pit of hell: Brought up in blood and cherished with scrawling Snakes, tormenting therewithal the damned souls of them, Here upon earth that careless live of thy commandment. I am the same. I am the same whom both my loathsome sisters hate, whom hell itself complains to keep within her race.
Whom every fearful soul detesteth with a curse, whom earth and Seas defy heavens loathing to behold, I am the same. I am the same sent from thy brother Pluto now, Thy brother Pluto King of hell and golden mines, Sent unto thee and these thy fellow Gods I am, From him to thee from him by me, to tell thee to thy face, He hath been lately rubbed and touched perhaps too near: which he neither can or will put up without revenge. If thou or any God the quarrel dares defend. And this it is. Thy daughter Venus thy proud daughter Venus here, Blabs it abroad and beareth all the world in hand, She must be thought the only Goddess of the world: Exalting and suppressing whom she likes best, Defacing altogether Lady Fortunes grace. Breaking her anchors down, dishonouring her name, Whose government thyself, thyself dost know. How sayst thou, dost thou not? Her father therefore thy brother Pluto sends, By me the messenger of discord and debate: Commanding or desiring, choose thou whether of both, Her honour still empire, she may maintain: Else on thy daughter Venus that lascivious dame, Himself will wreak his high despite on her.

sp.speaker: Jupiter.
sp.p: Depart foul fiend unto thy loathsome cell, where thou lamenting makes continual moan: Go tell my brother were it not for him, thou shouldst have rued thy bold presumption. Say thou thy message hath been largely heard, and bid him send his daughter Fortune now: whilst we are here the matter may have end. Dispatch.

sp.speaker: Tisiphone.
sp.p: I go. Give place thou air, open thou earth, gape hollow hell below, and unto all that live and breathe, I wish a world of woe.

sp.speaker: Jupiter.
sp.p: Ye powers divine be reconciled again, Depart from discord and extreme debate: within your breasts let love and peace remain, A perfect pattern of your heavenly state. whilom he go to hell condemning hate: Thus when the higher power is in one, Men upon earth will fly contention.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: Great God and father mine, your care and fear Of us and eke of all the world beside, that restless rules in his continual Sphere, whereby all things in perfect course abide: as one arrays another forth to slide. And this example may prevail for all, to work our wills according to your call: And I dare say presuming on the rest, the poison of this rancour is suppressed.

sp.speaker: Vulcan.
sp.p: How ye agree my masters I cannot tell, But were we abed, we two could agree well.

sp.speaker: Jupiter.
sp.p: Gramercy Mercury I know thy will Is ever pressed to further my desire: in sign whereof to quiet all things well, and to suppress betimes the secret fire, that I perceive would break and mount up higher. This to prevent content ye here to stay, to mark a while what for themselves they say. And Venus here I charge thee on my grace, Not that I found thee heretofore untrue: But for thine adversary is not yet in place, thou tell uprightly whence your quarrel grew: what words betwixt you thereof did ensue. Say lovely daughter tell us flat thy mind, they shall be blamed on whom the fault we find.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p:
O thou that governest every thing that Gods and men attempt, and with thy fearful thunderbolt their doings dost prevent. what hath thy daughter so deserved? what doth she silly dame: Before ye thus to be abused with undeserved blame?
Surely but that thy duty commands me now to speak, For such a trifling cause this way, my wrath I would not wreak. But she no marvel though she seek my seat thus to stain When otherways she cannot tell, advantage how to gain. But hence this hot despite, Hinc illae lacrimae: Because I say she could not prove, herself of power with me
For all you Godheads know, she pains but such as pleasure knew: She never grieves the groaning mind, where gladness never grew. She never overthrows but at the top of joy: For they that never tasted bliss, mislike not their annoy. But I torment the mind that never felt relief, I plague the wretch that never thought on comfort in his grief. That never had the hope of any happy chance: that never once so much as deemed I would his state advance. Think then which of us both are of the greater power, Once in his life or not at all to grant a lightning hour. I need not stand to make rehearsal here of all, For Gods and ghosts, yea, men and beasts unto my power are thrall. I dare appeal to you if I should look awry: Say father with your leave, in heaven who dares my word deny, And if I please to smile who will not laugh out right: Whereby my great omnipotence is known to every wight. I make the noble love the bastard in degree: I tame and temper all the tongues, that rail and scoff at me. What bird, what beast, what worm, but feeleth my delight
what lives or draweth breath, but I can pleasure or despite. Yet divers things there be that Fortune cannot tame, As are the riches of the mind, or else an honest name. Or a contented heart, still free from Fortunes power, But such as climb before they crawl, must drink the sweet with sour. Thy self O Jupiter didst grant sometimes to me: Of all things here beneath the Moon, I should the ruler be. Thou sayst I did deserve the honour of that praise, thyself didst once devise whereby my glory first to raise.
Is this my sovereignty, is this so glorious: Is this becoming thy renown, to quit thy daughter thus?

sp.speaker: Jupiter.
sp.p: Fear not fair Venus, neither be dismayed, Repose thee on the warrant of my word: What I have promised doubt not to be performed, the spareless destinies my will afford. Let this defend thee like a trusty Sword. But Lady Fortune cometh now we see, Welcome fair dame, what is thy will with me?

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p:
Ye sacred powers divine how should I now begin, Or which way should I couch my words your favours for to win. I may pour out my plaint, but thou mayst it redress, My Father humbly prayeth you to give me leave to speak, And pardon him that in his wrath he did your quietness break. I cannot but confess dread Gods I am not she, that seeks with Venus to compare in her supremacy. I am not of that power, yet am I of some might, which she usurping challengeth to keep me from my right. I grant she may do much with her alluring smiles, But soon your Godheads can perceive her words be full of wiles. What be ye tragedies, the terrors that she makes? Let us see the mighty Monarchs the kingdoms that she shakes. Poor soul she soundly lives with wanton sugared joys, triumphing in her own delight upon her foolish toys. Sometime she flattereth it in pleasure mixed with pain, Like to a fair sunshine day overcast with Clouds of rain But should I reckon up what things I can confound, what is it then, or what hath been, or shall for aye be found. Is not the wonder of the World a work that soon decays: therefore ye see all earthly things, are wearing out always As brittle as the glass, unconstant like the mind: as fickle as the whirling wheel, as wavering as the wind. Lo such am I that overthrows the highest reared tower: that changeth and supporteth Realms in twinkling of an hour. And send them hasty smart whom I devise to spoil: Not threatening or forewarning them but at a sudden smile.
Where joy doth most abound there I do sorrow place, and them I chiefly persecute that pleasure did embrace. what greater grief can fall to man in all his life, than after sweet to taste the sour, in peace to be at strife. It is a biting thought that fretteth on the heart, to say the time was when I joyed, though now oppressed with smart, If ever mighty King did scape untouched of me: if every year, or month, or day, or if an hour might be. Wherein I have not used to practise some exchange, Perhaps for this authority I might be thought to range. Too far beyond my right but even the very stars, the Heavens, the Planets, and the Seas hear witness of my scars.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: No more of that good dame you run too far at roam, I will take the pains to keep you short and call you nearer home. I pray you what is your might when all are well beloved?

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: The sweetest lovers in distress the sharper storms have proved

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: Perhaps for want of wealth but if their riches slack,

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: They are the very instrument whereby I work their woe,

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: What if their friends abound, then can they never lack?

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: The dearest friends are scattered when Fortune turns her toe.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: If they be noble born or of a Princely blood:

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: When Fortune frowns, that may procure more harm than do them good.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: But wise men evermore upon a Rock are set:

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: Yet can they not escape a scourge for Fortune hath a net.

sp.speaker: Jupiter.
sp.p: I will not in till things be well discerned, Affection shall not mar a lawful cause: By examples this may best be learned, In elder ages led within your laws. therefore a while hereof I mean to pause. And bring in Mercury in open view, the Ghosts of them that Love and Fortune slew.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p:
Thy word my will. thou triple headed Cerberus give place, And I command thee Caron with thy Ferry boat,
Transport the souls of such as may report, Fortune and Love and not in open sort. Let them appear to us in silent show, to manifest a truth that we must know.

div2.stage: Strike with his Rod three times

sp.speaker: Vulcan.
sp.p: Are ye mad my Masters, what a stir have we here? Lord have mercy upon us must the devil appear. Come away wife, when I pray thee come away, Down on your knees my Masters and pray.

div2.stage: Enter the show of Troylus and Cressida.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: Behold how Troylus and Cresseda, Cries out on Love that framed their decay.

sp.speaker: Vulcan.
sp.p: That was like the old wife when her Ale would not come, thrust a fire brand in the grout and scratched her bum.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: Alexander the great that all the world subdued, Curseth fell Fortune that did him delude.

sp.speaker: Vulcan.
sp.p: It is an honest grim sire at his first coming out believe me, And ye had stood in the wind ye might have smelt me.

div2.stage: Enter the show of Queene Dydo.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: Queen Dydo that Aeneas could not move, Stabbed herself and yielded unto love.

sp.speaker: Vulcan.
sp.p: The more fool she and she were my own brother, If my wife would not love me must not I love another?

div2.stage: Enter the shewe of Pompey and Caesar.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: Pompey and Caesar, the wonders of their time, By froward Fortune spoiled in their prime.

sp.speaker: Vulcan.
sp.p: They were served well enough, why could not they be content, with a Roach and a red Herring in the holy time of Lent.

div2.stage: Enter the showe of Leander and Hero.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: Leander presents them very loath: that felt the force of love and fortune both.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: Upon him I my sovereignty did show,

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: And think you dame my power she did not know.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: But it was I that dashed their delight,

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: After that I had proved my open might.

sp.speaker: Vulcan.
sp.p: What a scolding is here shall it even thus be? You look like an honest man in the Parish, I pray you make them agree.

sp.speaker: Jupiter.
sp.p: Content ye both I will hear no more of this, and Mercury surcease call out no more: I have bethought me how to work their wish, as you have often proved it heretofore. Here in this land within that Princely bower, there is a Prince beloved of his love? On whom I mean your sovereignties to prove. Venus, for that thy love thy sweet delight, thou shalt endure to increase their joy: and Fortune thou to manifest thy might, their pleasures and their pastimes thou shalt destroy. Overthwarting them with news of fresh annoy. And she that most can please them or despite, I will confirm to be of greatest might.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: Your Godhead hath devised as I desire, and I am gladly therewithal content:

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p:
And I am pressed to do as you require.
Now shall you see the proof of my intent. Take up your places here to work your will, When you have done the rest I shall fulfil.

sp.speaker: Vulcan.
sp.p: They are set a-sunning like a Crow in a gutter, what are they gone? And you will be quiet sirs, they will make ye good sport with their scolding anon. Are not these a sort of good mannerly Gods to get them thus away: I must take the pains to overtake them for I see they will not stay.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Why then my dear what is the greatest price in love?

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Absence of others griefs, the greatest that loving hearts can prove.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: But absence cannot minish love or make it less in aught:

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Yet nevertheless it leaves a doubt within the others thought

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: And what is that?

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Lest change of air should change the absent mind,

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: That fault is proper but to them whom jealousy makes blind.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: O pardon it for that the cause from whence it springs is such,

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: From whence is that?

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: My mother says from loving over much.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Your author I will not admit, that rests as it to prove,

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: But sure is it that jealousy, proceeds of fervent love.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Can that be fervent love wherein suspicion leads the mind,

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Most fervent love where so much love doth make ye fancy blind

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: But faithful love can never be wherein suspect doth dwell,

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: The faithful lovers do suspect because they love so well.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p:
My dear Fidelia, as I think thy love is such to me,
So fervent, faithful and unstained, as purer none can be: Admit occasions fall out then, that I must part from thee. tell me wilt thou mean space suspect inconstancy in me.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: If so I do impute it to the force of lovers laws, that oftentimes are touched with fear, whereas there is no cause.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: What have I heard? what do mine eyes behold: Dishonour to the house from whence I came: Unshamefast girl, forgetful, all too bold, and thou false traitor author of the same. Sufferest not for guerdon of thy due, the King my Fathers gracious countenance: But must thou clime ungrateful and untrue, these steps, at first thine honour to advance. Hath Fortune promised so much hope at first, to make thy conquest of a Princes child: And should I stand to question how thou durst, to leave to think she might be so beguiled. But words may not suffice to wreak this wrong, Hid under cloak of overhandy love: thou upstart fondling and forborne too long, to give such cause thy Princes ire to move.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p:
Nay nay good brother take it not so whot, the fault is mine, and I will bear the blame: And to return you an answer well I wot, How to defend the honour of my name. But for my love I am resolved in this, How ever you account of his defaults. with vowed affection wholly to be his. As one in whom I spy more special parts, than fall in foundlings of the baser kinds: to have a word not squaring with the place. But measure men by their unstained minds.
Let fortune be to virtue no disgrace, For fortune when and where it likes her majesty: With clouds can cover birth and highest degree.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: What Dame, and are you shameless in your shame? No Mistress, no, it will not so be let past: But wilful Wench this new attempted game, Ere it be won will ask another cast. And Lady, cloak his virtues as you will, He will be but as I said, a fondling still.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Erst had I thought my Lord a man so wise as you, Son to a Prince, Scholar to him that depth of learning knew. Among many lessons, none this rule could wisely find, to have the government of wrath and rancour of your mind. What high offence is given unto your fathers grace: I take it nothing needful here to reason of the case. But stand he less content, or pleased here withal, My Lord, that thus you should mislike the cause is very small. The unremoved love I bear my Lady here, Whose countenance my comfort is: that holds my love as dear. Commands me to digest such hard and bitter words, as not with credit of your state, your honour here affords. Else Prince persuade thyself: my mind were not so base, to pocket, but for such respects so hard and foul disgrace. And this Lady Hermione for aught that men do know, By birth may be as nobly born, as prince Armenio.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: Traitor thou shalt not joy that proud comparison,

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: My good Hermione, come hence let him alone.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: Nay Dame it likes me not that you should go,

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Whether thou wilt Armenio she shall, though thou say no.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: What shall she villain?

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Help, help alas.

div2.stage: Enter Phizanties, a Lord, and Penulo.

sp.speaker: Phyzan.
sp.p:
What stir is here? what means this broil begun?
Give me to know the occasion of this strife, How falls it out? Armenio my Son Hath wound received by stroke of naked knife, Say to me straight: what one hath done this deed: His blows are big that makes a Prince to bleed.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: My sovereign father, pardon his offence, whose grief of mind is greater than his wound: My rightful quarrel yields me safe defence, and here they stand that guilty must be found.

sp.speaker: Armenio,
sp.p: Traitor (O King) unto your Majesty, Whose proud attempt doth touch your grace so near: as what may be the greatest villainy, Upon recital shall be opened here. My sister and your far unworthy child, Forgetting love and fear of Gods and thee: and honour of her name is thus beguiled. To love this Gentleman whom here you see. Hermione whom for a Jewel of some price, Old Hermit give your highness long ago: and for I gave rebuke to your devise, In gallant thought he would not take it so. But as it seems to do my body good, I thank him deigned himself to let me blood.

sp.speaker: Phyzan.
sp.p:
Hermione? and hast thou done this deed? and couldst thou shrine such treason in thy thought? Armenio jest not with thy hurt take heed, and thou fond girl whose stained blood hath wrought, How hath mine age and honour been abused? My princely care Hermione of thee? the fault so great it cannot be excused. and you enforced the shame thereof to see. But far we fear some farther ill may fall: through love and hate of one and of the other: Her foolish love I mean, and therewithal. The hot disdain and stomach of her brother, Hermione, way what our pleasure is.
Whilom thou knowest we entertain thee willingly: Now seeing thou hast done so far amiss, to reach above thy reach unorderly. In milder words because we love thee well, Lo, we discharge thee of our princely Court: thou mayst no longer with Fidelia dwell, Forbidden to her presence to resort. Hold my reward, that am no bitter Judge, and wend thy way wherever thou likest to go? this only way I take to end the grudge, and stop the love that each to other owe. Among such haps as might my mind content, Whereof the gracious Gods have given me store: I count this one if thus I might prevent, the furthest outrage of this swelling sore.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Alas, now have I lived too long I see, Confounded so to yield to fortunes will: My sovereign Prince offended thus with me, and I adjudged to death though living still. Ah my good Lord whom I have honoured long, long may your highness joy this highest place: thyself the root and cause of mine own wrong, But must I leave to view my Ladies face? And banished from my Princes royal Court, to wander as erst the unhappy Oedipus: Whose pain my foes will make their chiefest sport, My most unhappy chance will have it thus.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: No force forsooth, unpitied might he die, that to his sovereign means such villainy.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Such villainy? who ever meant more good?

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: The venom of thy villainy withstood.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p:
Armenio, I forbear thee here for reverence, Yet by my Princes leave in my defence. I may allege I loved thy sister here, which love though I am like to buy full dear. Yet is her love more precious than the price:
But since hard hap prevents our late device. Long live my Lord, long live my Ladies grace, God send them friends as loyal in my place. And trust me then their fortune shall be such, as not thy love shall ever prove so much.

sp.speaker: Phyzan.
sp.p: Hermione, give me thy hand, adieu, think this is done to avoid a further ill, and double mischief that might else ensue, For my sake cease to love Fidelia still. Unequal love is enemy to rest, She is too young to love thee as she should: and thou Hermione canst conceive the rest, My meaning is she loves not as we would. time may afford to both your hearts desires: New choice to cool these newly kindled fires.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Never alas, never will be the day, that I shall leave to love Hermione: Sooner shall natures course quite altered be, than I shall leave dear Knight to honour thee. Good Father let him stay, who if he part, Against law is like to steal away my heart.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: May it please your grace to keep the body here, It is like enough the heart will honour near.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: My Lord, laugh not oppressed souls to scorn, Losers they say may easily be forborne.

sp.speaker: Phyzan.
sp.p: Forbear these words and thou Fidelia, these misbeseeming foolish passions stay. Let it suffice that thou shalt live in Court, Where if among the jolly brave resort. Of sundry knights of noble personage, Worthy thy love for gifts and parentage. thou shalt espy some such as we do like, Our favours shall not be too far to seek.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Ah my Hermione.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Sweet Lady mine farewell. Farewell the curteoust Dame that on the earth doth dwell.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: Sir now you are packing let me know your walk: For I have that may not be past without some talk. Nor stands it with mine honour to let thee bear it clear: But I will make thee know Armenios blood is dear.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: My Lord, I make no challenge with offence, But first I will prepare for my defence.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: So sir, you are aforehand, keep you so: and reckon of Armenio for thy vowed foe. Go wend thy ways, obscurer than the night: and Fortune for revenge plague thee with spite.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Farewell my cruel foe, not thou, nor Fortune may, add more unto the miseries that I have felt today. Nor but by safe restored unto this happy place, Can Gods or Fortune make amends in this distressed case. Then cease Hermione to utter speech of this, Words not suffice this endless woe, but death iwis. and part thou from the place a dead and liveless man, Robbed of thy senses and thy joy, since first this stir began.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Ah my good Lord, my good Lord Hermione.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p:
I am indeed as thou dost say Hermione. For that I am Hermione, I am
the unhappiest wight that ever hither came.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Ah my good Lord, would Gods poor Penulo, Might any way but mitigate this woe. and pleaseth it your honour to command, My service or the help of head or hand. Penulo my worthy Lord would prove as just, as he whom best your honour likes to trust. Say what it is wherein my secrecy, May aid your Lordship in this extremity.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Penulo, since thou so friendly here dost proffer me, the uttermost of aid that lies in thee. I do remember that which brought to pass, Would make me half so happy as I was.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Say it my Lord, and constantly I vow it: It shall go hard but Penulo will do it.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Gramercy gentle friend: then thus it is, The Lady of my life Fidelia is. Of whom I am, I know beloved no less, than she of me my gracious mistress. Severed by Fortune and our cruel foe, My Lord her brother Prince Armenio. Now couldst thou Penulo thyself behave, On trust to bring my Lady to the cave. Where whilom lovers we were wont to meet, in secret sort each other for to greet. She wots it well and every corner knows, and every uncouth step that thither goes. For what is not sharpe sighted lovers see, this is the sum of my desire to thee. Accomplish this, and this in silence done, My happiness will be again begun.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: My Lord I see whereunto this talk doth tend, I have this lesson at my fingers end. No more ado: betake you to your flight, we will make a plaster for the sore ere night. But such a one as if it be applied, Shall do more grief than ease when it is tried.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Penulo I yield my life into thy hands,

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Ye, do sir, as now the matter stands,

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Hold Penulo and I will look for thee,

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: You will not look for them that come with me.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: I will be gone and live to see my dear.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p:
Do so sir and perchance be never the nearer. This is a step that first we use to climb, We that forsooth take hold on every time: Men of all hours, whose credit such as spites, in heat forsooth hath called us Parasites.
But let them spite and we will bite as fast, But Penulo thou spendest words in waste. A fool Hermione, that for hurting thee, One slender trust will give a knave his fee.

div2.stage: Strike vp Fortunes triumphes with Drummes> and Trumpets.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: Behold what Fortune if she list can do, High mistress of the rolling wheel of chance: to overturn and who can do thereto, Or graciously when please her to advance. Lo Lordings this is Fortunes Empery, as in her pleasure to be changing still: Herein consisteth Fortunes sovereignty, that Fortune can on earth do what she will. When men have builded on the surest grounds, their strong devises Fortunes power confounds.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: Not all in haste you do not so intend, You have begun but I must make an end.

div2.stage: Enter Bomelio solus like an Hermite.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p:
He that hath lost his hope and yet desires to live, He that is overwhelmed with woe, and yet would counsel give. He that delights to sigh to walk abroad alone, to drive away the weary time with his lamenting moan. He that in his distress despaireth of relief, Let him begin to tell his tale to rip up all his grief.
And if that wretched man can more than I recite, Of fickle Fortunes froward check and her continual spite. Of her unconstant change, of her discourtesy, I will be partner with that man to live in misery. When first my flowering years began to bud their prime, Even in the April of mine age, and May month of my time
When like the tender Kid new weaned from the teat: In every pleasant springing Mead, I took my choice of meat. When simple youth devised to lengthen his delight: Even then not dreaming I on her, she poured out her spite. Even then she took her Key, and turned all her strings, to sing my woe, list Lordings now my tragedy begins. Behold me wretched man that served his Prince with pain, that in the honour of his praise esteemed my greatest gain. Behold me wretched man that for his public weal, Refused not with thousand foes, in bloody wars to deal. Behold me wretched man, whose travel pain and toil: was ever pressed to save my friends from force of foreign spoil. And see my just reward, look on my recompense: Behold by this for labours past, what guerdon cometh thence. Not by my fiercest foes in doubtful fight with us, But by my fawning friends, I was confounded thus. One word of his despite in question called my name, two words of his untrusty tongue brought me to open shame
Then was I banished the City, Court and town: then every hand that held me up, began to pull me down. O that the righteous Gods should ever grant the power, that smoothest sands and greenest bogs, should soonest me devour. Yet that I might descry the better their devise, Here have I lived almost five years disguised in secret wise. And now somewhat it is but what I cannot tell, provokes me forward more than wont to leave my darksome sell. And in my crooked age instead of mirth and joy, with broken sighs in doleful tunes to sing of mine annoy.
Go walk the path of plaint, go wander wretched now,
In uncouth ways, blind corners fit for such a wretch as thou. there feed upon thy woe, fresh thoughts shall be thy fare, Musing shall be thy waiting maid, thy carver shall be care. thy dainty dish shall be of fretting melancholy, and broken sobs with hollow sighs thy savoury sauce shall be. But further ere I walk my servant I will send, Into the town to buy such things as now he can intend. What Lentulo.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Anon forsooth.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: What Lentulo come forth.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Anon forsooth.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Why when I say.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Anon forsooth.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: You naughty lout, come out sir knave, come away.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Will you not give one leave to pull down his points, what and he should his breeches bewray?

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Get you to the market and buy such things as needful are for us.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Such things as needful are for us, and what are those I pray? First there is needful for us a pot of porridge, for I had none this many a day: And then there are needful for us a feather bed, for I lie on a bottle of hay. And then there is most needful for us a pretty proper wench for and to laugh and play.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Go buy us some victuals and hie thee home.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p:
Now farewell Master mine good gentle master mome. Have you seen such a logger headed fool to say, Go go, good Lentulo, to buy my victuals so, and give me money no. But for the names sake, 'swounds I were as good serve a master of clouts: He will do nothing all day long but sit on his arse, as my mother did when she made pouts.
And then a looks a this fashion, and thus and thus again, and then what do ye? By my troth I stand even thus at him and laugh at his simplicity. Hath the best manners in the world to bid a man fall to his meat, And then I say, I thank you forsooth master and I could tell what to eat. We two, look you that is I and he, can lie a bed a whole night and a day: And we eat and we had it, it vattons a man look on my cheeks else, are they not fallen away? Well, I must jog to the town, and I will tell you what shift I make there: Marry ye shall promise me not to steal it away. When I come to a rich man's gate, I make a low leg and then I knock there. And then I begin to cry in at the Key hole, that I may be sure they shall hear. God save my good master and my good mistress, a poor boy a piece of bread and meat for Gods sake.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Heigh merely trick, am I not a knave for the nonce, That can dispatch two errands at once? I have both told her even as I should do, And told my young master to meet with him too. Now he like a Gentleman for the valour of his mind, Hath sworn by his honour not to stay long behind. The desire of revenge pricketh him forward so, That I am sure he will not let but to go. And that with all haste possible he may: Then tantara tara we shall have good play. I like such a knave so can tickle them all, To set noble men at brabble and brawl,

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Save you sir young master and you be a gentleman,

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Whoreson peasant seest thou not what I am?

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p:
Troth sir I see you have a good doublet and a pair of hose
But now a days there is so many goes
So like Gentlemen, that such a poor fellow as I, Know not how a Gentleman from a knave to spy.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Thou mayst perceive I am no such companion, I am a Gentleman, a Courtier, and a merry frank franion.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Then thou merry companion, thou whoreson frank franion, Why hast thou abused the law: What goodman skip-jack, in faith with thwick thwack your bones will I claw. Come about sir knave.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Cots my passion what a merry mate have we here?

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p:
Give me your hand sir, faith I was bold to brush the dust out of your gear. Pray sir tell me, they say in the Country It is a common guise
That Gentlemen nowadays cannot see with both eyes.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Its a lie knave, I know few Gentlemen blind:

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: No sir what will you lay and I can find, One with a wet finger that is stark blind.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: It may be so, but I think thou canst not,

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: You will lay do wager on it.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: What should I lay, Thou hast no money I am sure to pay.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: No faith sir, but I will tell you what our wager shall be, Because I am not able to lay any money. I will lay three round raps on the ribs with my cudgel here

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Soft, let me look first if there be no blind man near. Content Ifaith that bargain shall stand:

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Then sir I must be so bold as to search your purse out of hand.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: My purse sir wherefore?

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: By my troth sir no more but to try, if you be not as blind a Gentleman in the purse as I.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: I use not to carry my money in a purse, All in a pocket, well never a whit the worse.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: I must search your pocket.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: What if it be else where?

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Where soever it is I must seek out this gear. I will not lose my wager that is certain: Very well sir will you put me to pain.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Have I never a weapon, I will look, I pray thee be content

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: You shall have your wager sir as it was meant.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Hold thy hands good fellow and I will do any thing for thee: I perceive a wise man of a fool overtaken may be.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Thou blind Gentleman, unless it be for my commodiosity, I will teach thee to be blind and go so bravely.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: I will do any thing for thee if thou strike me no more, Because I perceive thou art almost as poor. As my self am and yet there is somewhat in thee, I will prefer thee to a service in the Court presently.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Ha wilt thou do so?

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: That I will.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Wilt thou do so indeed, Swear to me by thy ten commandments in thy Creed.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: I do so.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Troth then we are friends, say nothing I pray: and you shall see me prove a rank runaway. Why when a man may be a Courtier and live at ease, Should a not leave his old master to please. Sirrah blind gentleman, we too blind gentlemen, and do as thou promised here, Perchance I may be as good to thee as two pots of Beer, I will go with thee Ifaith, gaw let us be gone,

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Soft tarry a while I will go with thee anon.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: How thinkest thou Penulo, am I not provided now?

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: I warrant sir a shall have a cold pull of you. And a begin to make an other brawl,

sp.speaker: Armenio,
sp.p:
Farewell when thou wilt, I trust I shall
Meet with him: am I not almost at the tree,

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: That same is it sir.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Sirrah what is he?

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: What carest thou, come gaw thou with me, Why I shall have but an ill favoured Courtier of ye.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Now for a runaway God send us good chance, Then maids at your marriage I mean me to dance.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: Now serves the time to wreak me of my foe, My dastard foe that to dishonour me: in privy corners seeks to shame me so, that my discredit might his credit be. And hath my father from thy tender youth, Vouchsafe to bring thee up? did I therefore Believe so earnestly thy perjured truth, advancing still thine honour evermore. That not contented with a common wrack, thou shouldest intend the ruin of us all: And when thou seemest afraid to turn thy back, to make a glory of our greater fall. Before thou triumph in thy treachery, Before thou scape untouched for thy sin: Let never fates nor Fortune favour me, But wretched let me live and die therein. Few words shall serve, my deeds shall prove it now: That ere I sleep I mean to meet with you.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p:
Behold the shifts that faithful love can make, See what I dare adventure for thy sake: In case extreme make virtue of a need, But hence the grief which maketh my heart to bleed. My love and life where ever that thou be, I am in dole constrained to follow thee. Hence sprung the hell of my tormented mind,
The fear of some misfortune yet behind. If thou escape the peril of distress, My fear and care is twenty times more less. No reason It is that I should live in joy, When thou art wrapped in fetters of annoy. Nor to that end I swear to be thy wife, To live in peace with thee and state of life. But as to dwell at ease in pleasures lap, Even so to bear some part of thy mishap. And so to draw in equal portion still, Of both our Fortunes either good or ill. And sith the lots of our unconstant fate, Have turned our former bliss to wretched state, I am content to tread the woeful dance, That sounds the measure of our hapless chance. I will wait thy coming, long thou wilt not stay, Hie Jove defend and keep thee in the way.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Now weary lay thee down, thy fortune to fulfil, Go yield thee captive to thy care to save thy life or spill. The pleasures of the field, the prospect of delight, The blooming trees, the chirping birds are grievous to thy sight. The hollow craggy rock, the shrieking Owl to see, To hear the noise of serpents hiss that is thy harmony. For as unto the sick all pleasure is in vain, So mirth unto the wounded mind, increaseth but his pain. But heavens? what do I see? thou Nymph or Lady fair, Or else thou goddess of the grove, what makest thee to repair. To this unhaunted place thy presence here unfit,

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p:
Ancient father let it not offend thee any whit. To find me here alone I am no Goddess I, But a mortal maid subject to misery. And better that I might lament my heavy moan,
I secret came abroad to recreate my self a while alone.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Take comfort daughter mine for thou hast found him then That is of others all that live, the most accursedest man. O, I have heard it said our sorrows are the less, If in our anguish we may find a partner in distress.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p:
O father but my grief relieved cannot be, My hope is fled, my help in vain, my hurt my death must be
Yet not the common death of life that here is led: But such a death as ever kills, and yet is never dead.

sp.speaker: Bomelio,
sp.p: Fair maid, I have been well acquainted with that fit, Sometime injured with the like, I learn to comfort it. Come rest thee here with me within this hollow cave, There will I reckon up at large the horrors that I have.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: I thank you father but I must needs walk another way,

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Nay gentle damsel be content a while with me to stay.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: The longer that I stay with you, the greater is my grief.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: The longer that you stay with me, the sooner is relief.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: I am provided other ways, good father let me go,

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: To him that offereth thee no wrong, be not uncourteous so.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Perhaps another time, I will come and visit thee,

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Both then and now if so you please you shall right welcome be.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: Shall she be welcome unto thee old wretch indeed, I will welcome both of you come maid away with speed.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: O brother:

sp.speaker: Armenio,
sp.p: Brother peace.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Good father help me now.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Have I no weapons wretch that I am? well youth, I will meet with you.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: Must you be gone? is this your meeting place? Come get you home and pack you sir apace. Were it not for reverence of thine age I swear, Thou shouldest accurse the time I met thee here. But Ifaith sister my Father shall welcome you,

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Go tell thine arrant if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Hermione adieu. Ten times adieu, farewell forever now.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: I thank thee Fortune that thou didst this deed allow.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Thou Heaven and Earth, and ye eternal lamps, That restless keep his course in order due: Thou Phoebo bright that scatterest the damps, Of darksome night, I make my plaints to you. And thou Alecto hearken to my call, Let fall a Serpent from thy Snaky hair: Tisiphone, be swift to plague them all, That make a pastime of my care and fear. And thou O Jove, that by thy great foresight, Rulest the earth, and reignest above the Skies: That wreakest the wrongs of them that master right, Against the wretches that thy name despise. And Rodomantes, thou Judge of hateful hell, Where damned ghosts continual moaning make: Send forth a fury that may further well, the just revenge that here I undertake. Hence forth accursed be thou evermore, Accursed all thou takest in hand to do: The time, the day, accursed be the hour, the earth, the air, and all that long thereto. Dole and despair henceforth be thy delight, Wrapped now in present, and in woes to come: To wail the day and weep the weary night, And from this time henceforth I strike thee dumb. Thinkst thou I knew thee not, yes well iwis, And that thy sister daughter to my Prince: Now brag abroad what thou hast got by this, So live thou dumb, that be thy recompense. And when thy ghost forsakes thy body quite: Vengeance I wish upon thy soul to light.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Good even good Father, pardon my rudeness here:

sp.speaker: Bomelio,
sp.p: O joy and grief I will dissemble yet my cheer.

sp.speaker: Hermione,
sp.p:
Good sir methought I heard you speak of one right now
Daughter unto a Prince that made me bold to trouble you

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: I spake of such a one indeed.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Why do you know her name?

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Fidelia. Why do you ask? what do you know the same?

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Yea father that I do, I know, and knew her well, But did you wish those plagues to light on her I pray you tell.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: On her the Gods forbid, but on that wretched wight, Her brother that from hence right now perforce conveyed her quite.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Alas what do I hear, good father tell me true. Hath she been here?

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: She was.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: She was? Where is she now?

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Gone back again.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Gone back: with whom?

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Her brother.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Her brother: how?

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: He secret watched here, and when she should have staid A while with me, he rushed out, and her from hence conveyed.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Confounded in my grief and can it suffered be? And shall he make a brag at home of his despite to me? First let me die a thousand deaths, draw, run and meet with him,

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Tarry my Son it is in vain they are not at home I win. Let him alone, he will not make great reckoning of his gain,

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Wretch that thou art for lingering everlasting shall be thy pain. Continual thy complaint, aye during still thy woe: Why madest thou not more haste to come and first of all to know.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Content thy self my son, torment not so thy mind: Assuage the sorrows of thy heart in hope some help to find.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p:
Some help, O Father, no all help comes too late,
I am the only man alive the most unfortunate. I see thy loyalty, I see thy faithful love, Else never durst thou this attempt adventured to prove.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Take comfort thereby my son.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: I am the man I say, That love and Fortune once advanced, but now have cast away. The joy, the sweet delight, the rest I had before, Fell to my lot, that now the loss, my plague might be the more. O Fortune froward dame, wilt thou be never sure, Most constant in unconstancy, I see thou wilt endure.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Accuse not Fortune son, but blame thy love therefore, For I perceive thou art in love, and then thy trouble is more.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Father if this be love to lead a life in thrall, To think the rankest poison sweet to feed on honey gall. To be at war and peace, to be in joy and grief, then farthest from the hope of help, where nearest is relief, To live and die, to freeze and sweat, to melt and not to move, if it be this to live in love, father I am in love.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Why did you not possess your Lady then at home,

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: At home, where is it sir? alas for I have none. Brought up I know not how, and born I know not where, when I was in my childhood given unto my Prince then here. Of whom I can not tell, wherefore I little know, But now cast out to seek my fate unhappy where I go. There dare I not be seen, here must I not abide. Did ever more calamities unto a man betide:

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: My heart will burst if I forbear amidst this misery, Behold thy father thou hast found my son Hermione. Thy father thou hast found, thy father I am he,

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: But is it possible my father you should be.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Even from my first exile here have I lived forlorn, And once I gave thee to my prince, for thou was noble born. And now he gives me thee, and welcome home again,

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p:
This is my recompense for all my former pain. Dear father glad I am to find you here alive,
By your example I may learn with froward chance to strive.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Come son, content thee now, within a cave to dwell, I will provide for thy redress, and all things shall be well. A darksome den must be thy lofty lodging now,

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Father I am well content to take such part as you. Here is a breathing pit after hard mischance, O gracious Venus once vouchsafe thy servants to advance.

div2.stage: Strike vp a noise of Viols, Venus triumphe.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: Behold what love can work for their delight, That put affiance in her Deity: Though heaven and earth against them bend their might, Yet in the end theirs is the victory. I will in them and they triumph in me, Let Fortune frown I will uphold their state, Yea seem they never so unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: Brag not too much, what thinkst thou I have done? Nay soft not yet, my sport is not begun.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Come away with thy basket thou logger-headed jack, I think thy basket be cloven to thy back.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: My back and my basket, look dost thou not see, When my basket is on my back then my back is under me. And O this basket, wots thou wherefore I keep it so close, For all the love of my heart within this basket goes.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Thy love with a wanion? are you in love sir then with your leave:

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p:
What an ass art thou, couldst thou not all this time perceive?
That I never sleep but when I am not awake, And I eat and I eat till my belly would ache. And I fall away like a gammon of Bacon, Am I not in love when I am in this tacon? Callest thou this the Court, would I had never come thither, to be caught in Cupido, I faint I faint, O gather me gather

sp.speaker: Penolo.
sp.p: Come up and be hanged, alack poor Lentulo, Tell me with whom thou art in love so.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: You kill me and you make me tell her name, no no, O terrible torments that trounce in my toe. Love my Masters is a perilous matter, how it runs out of my nose, Its now in my back, now in my belly, O now in the bottom of my hose.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: The pestilence there, what is she my boy? I will make her love thee again be she never so coy.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p:
Wilt thou so? O Gods of love that word plucks up my heart, I will tell thee sirrah even as we two at ye Court gate did wait
Didst thou not mark a goodly Lady, O Lady, Lady, why should not I as well as he, my dear Lady. Didst thou not see her come in with a golden lock, She had a fine gown on her back and a passing netherstock.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Well sir proceed, I remember her very well, its the Dukes daughter the sot means I can tell.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Now sirrah there was a little dapper ass with her that went before, When I saw him I came in sneaking more and more. To have heard them talk, ah crouching on is good, For when he had talked a while I had a come in, with I forsooth no forsooth that I would. And she would have looked upon me then more acquaintance we should have:

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: An excellent devise, ah sirrah you are an excellent knave.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p:
Tu autem tum autem, I have it in me, but sirrah wots thou what now? As god juggle me when I came near them I tell thee true:
The same squall did nothing but thus, I know what is what
And I ran before him and did thus too.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: A pox on you what meant you by that?

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: What mean I, marry sir he meant to give her a box on the ear if she spake to me, And I meant to give him another box on the ear sir he should see.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: You should have bestowed it where you meant it then, Must you strike me and mean other men,

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: It was nothing fellow but for samples sake,

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Well sir I am content this once it to take. But sirrah, you must know that squall is the Dukes son, That now by mischance is stricken stark dumb. In fetching home his sister that ran away from hence:

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Is she then a runaway, O passing wench. I thought as much, now good Lord to see, That she and I now akin should be. O cuckally luck, O heavy chance ho: I runaway, she runaway, go together go.

sp.speaker: Pennulo.
sp.p: But all the Court laments and sore weeps for it:

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: All the Court thou liest ye Court gate weeps not a whit.

div2.stage: Enter Bomelio like a counterfeite phisition.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p:
Bien veneu chi diue ve mi nou intendite signeur no.
I have a piece of work in hand now that all the world must not know.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: 'Swounds the devil a gods name what is he:

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Some Spaniard or foreign stranger he seems to be.

p.foreign: Dio vou salui signiore, e voutre gratio, pauero mouchato.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: I have no pleasure in thee I pray thee get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: What would you sir?

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Monsieur, par ma foy am one have the grand knowledge in the science of physic, Can make them hole have been all life sick. Can make the sick see, and the dumb speak: Can make the lame go and be never so weak.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Can you so sir, what Country man are you I pray?

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: I be Italian neopolitane, ye come a Uedice a the other day,

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: And you can speak any Peddlers French tell me what I say.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: No point intend Seigniora.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: You are an Ass: I can expose him I,

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Monsieur, parley petite ye heard now hereby. There be a noble man dumb, that made me stay: If me no help him me carry no head away.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Will you venture your head to help him indeed: Well sir, I will tell the Duke with all possible speed. Tarry me here I will return by and by, Excellent luck, it falls out happily.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Will you venture your head sirrah blockhead you:

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: You be the ass head me can tell that is true.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p:
'swounds, O but that I am in love thou shouldest know
What it were to move my vengeance so.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Come hither sirrah, me speak with you, me can tell, You are the runaway from your master, ah very well.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: You gods and devils eke what do you mean to do, Shall I be known a runaway, for and to shame me too, I a runaway sirrah, go with your uplandish go, I am no runaway I would you should know.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: You no runaway from your master in the wood, When he send you to market ah no point good.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: O furies fell, and hags of hell, with all that therein be, What do ye mean to shame me clean, and tell him thus of me. Hear you sirrah you are no devil, master and iwis you were, I would lamback the devil out of you for all your gear.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Diauolo, ah fie fie me no diauolo me very fury, Let me see your basket what meat you buy.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Look in my basket, O villain rascal tarry, stay, Hath opened it: out alas my love is quite flown away. My love is gone, my love is gone out of the basket there, Prepare therefore to kill thy self, farewell my friends so dear.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Ah what you do man.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Uplandish hence away,

sp.speaker: Bomelio,
sp.p: What you do man, no point yourself to slay. Come thee be hanged.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Alas, O my neck alas. O frying pan of my head uplandish now, I am worse than ever was. Adieu farewell, farewell my love.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Your love? if you be in love then do as I bid do, And you slave your love away with you too.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Uplandish O my friend if thou do so for me, Hold here my hand, thy fellow friend and partner will I be.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Go you then and get me some fine fine fine colosse, And with the Marigold leave all to mus your nose.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Ah my nose my nose, O God is my nose in my hand, Uplandish leave your signs without them I can understand.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: And come a me hither with a gold ring in your mouth fast, I make the Lady go with you whether list at last.

sp.speaker: Lentulo
sp.p: O let me brace thy cursed corpse, O now I live again, I will go get apparel straight, although be to my pain. It is the apparel, a Marigold and a ring,

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Noting else, and you them bring.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Bring them, yes I warrant thee, I will bring them by and by, Now good man Venus lend thy hand, and lady Vulcan hie.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p:
A good beginning I am not yet descried, They know not me but I know them too well: Disguised thus their counsels may be tried, And I may safe return unto my sell. Where I have left my solitary Son, Twixt hope and fear in doubt and danger too: Till I return to tell him what is done, which for his sake I have devised to do. Eternal Gods that know my true intent, And how unjustly wronged I have been: Vouchsafe all secret dangers to prevent,
And further me as yet you do begin, Sufficeth you my travel heretofore, My hunger, cold, and all my former pain, Hear make an end and plague me now no more. Contented then, at rest I will remain: But hark some comes dissemble then again.

div2.stage: Enter the Duke, his Sonne, and Penulo.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: My Lord yon is the man whom I have told to you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: My friend I am informed that by thy worthy skill, In Physic thou art able to recover at thy will. The strangest cures that be: if this be true indeed, As grant the Gods it may, I pray thee then with speed, Provide for our relief, recover this my son: Unto his speech, whom here thou seest before us to be dumb.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: You no take care for that me noble Prince, Me make him speak again, or me never come hence.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Thrice welcome them to us dispatch it out of hand, And thou shalt bless the time that ere thou camest unto our land.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Let me see him, you hear me: Ah that well turn hither, no like it truly.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: By the mass this Physic is an excellent art, It picks such a deal of gold out of every part.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Well well, me now see what this matter mean, Noble Prince this thing be done by Magic clean. It is true that me tell, me perceive it plain, No natural pediment, but conjuring certain.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: O double treble woe, my son how cometh this? He saith by Magic it is wrought, unnatural it is. Dost thou remember aught that so it should appear? Or canst thou any reason make it should be true we hear? What means he by these signs, can any one express,

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p:
If you give me leave sir to say as I guess. Me thinks he should mean there was some old man, That threatened to be revenged on him than.
It is so you may see, he confirms it again:

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Condemned be that man to everlasting pain. Perpetual his annoy, continual his unrest: O that I had him here to plague as I thought best. But learned sir, is there no way is there no remedy: Can there be found out no devise, the Charm to mollify. Good sir, if any thing what ever that it be: Let spare no cost, my will is such I will allow it thee.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Indeed and by my trot, there is nothing, But me am very loath the same to bring. Yet without that me am sure me tell, Your son again be never more well.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Good father tell it me, what ever should befall, Mine be the danger, mine the loss, you shall be pleased for all. In any case express it then.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Fat then me will, If you no have your son be so dumb still, You must get the grand enemy that he now have, and in the tenderest part his dearest blood crave. Therewith must you wash his tongue a string, Noting but that will his speech bring.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: The dearest blood in the tenderest part, Of his great enemy, O grief to my heart. Will nothing else cure his disease,

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Noting by my trot but do as you please.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: My son, my wretched son, and whom dost thou suppose, Thy greatest enemy amongst thy Fathers foes. It is Hermione, It is he and none but he: He hath now proved him self indeed thy greatest enemy. Where lives the wretch? that he were taken and we revenged be.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p:
And must his dearest blood in his tenderest part, Help him to his speech, that is an excellent art. But what part is that my masters now about a man, That is the tenderest, guess it and ye can. I can tell what part a woman thinks tenderest to be, and there is dear blood in it, but benedicitie.
And do you think sir there is none but he, That can be thought his greatest enemy? I have heard it said there is no hate, Like to a brother or a sisters if they fall at debate. I will not say but you may think it as well as I, If you mark since her coming home his sisters cruelty. And the continual rancour she beareth unto him:

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Is then maid his sister, by God then he say tim. By my faith and truth sir, It is true what he say, His sister be his greatest enemy today.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: And must I kill my daughter to help my son to speech, I will never do it.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: See how a doth beseech. I would all our beggars were of his quality, They should not brawl with a man then so for his money.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: You kill your Daughter fie no point so, Her dearest blood in tenderest part me will show. It is in her paps, her dugs for there be the tenderest part, And the blood the dearest, it comes from the heart. So she be pricked a little under the breast, And wash his tongue he speak with the best.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: This thing is somewhat easier if she consent thereto, If not, I can enforce and make her it to do. Penulo, dispatch, and to my Marshall bear, This Signet for a token, that he send her to us here.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
He that hath felt the zeal, the tender love and care, The fear the grief that parents dear unto their children bare
He may, and only he conceive mine inward woe, Distracted thus twixt two extremes that hale me to and fro, Sometime mistrusting that, and then misliking this: Have parents such a cause of joy, or is it such a bliss. To see the offspring of their seed in health before them now, O little know they what mishap awaits the death for you.
But son, my dearest son, recomfort thou thy mind, Fight against fortune and thy fates, when they be most unkind, And since I understand what may recover thee, Make sure account of it: my self will do it presently. But sir, I pray you least my daughter should by fear, Or flight of it be sore abashed, be always ready here. To stench her wound when you see good,

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Awe awe she lose but a little blood. Two or tree ounces shall be the very most. Yonder she come, is no she?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: The same is she.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Father, they say you sent for me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Yea daughter I did so. And mark what I shall say to thee, the cause thereof to show. Thou seest thy brother here,

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: In name but not in kind,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Well hold thy peace I say, and let me tell my mind. Thy brother here I say thou seest him stricken dumb, And as this learned man declares, by magic it is done. But yet there is a way, one thing he telleth me, that will restore him to his speech, that resteth inwardly. Which though I might command, yet I entreat to know, Be not so stubborn or unkind, thy furtherance to show.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Noble father you can not say, but hitherto I have, Been most obedient to your will in all things that you crave. But herein pardon me, if this I do deny, I never can be made to grant help to mine enemy. My deadly enemy, worse than my mortal foe, And such a one is he to me for I have found him so. That laboured evermore to cross me with despite, But I am glad I may so well his courtesy requite.

sp.speaker: Penulo
sp.p: A right woman, either love like an Angel, Or hate like a Devil, in extremes so to dwell.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: But daughter I command, and I thy Father too.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: And I your daughter any thing that lawful is to do.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Is it not right and lawful both, to help thy brothers woe?

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Its neither right nor lawful sir to help my deadly foe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: If he have been thy foe, he may become thy friend,

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: And when I see that come to pass, I may some succour send.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: But wherefore shouldest thou be so cruel unto him?

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Because unto my dearest friend so spiteful he hath been.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Nay stubborn girl, but then I will constrain thee I, Lay hold on her my self will then sith she doth it deny.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Assist me righteous Gods in this extremity,

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Ah pardon, pardon, please you let me a while with her alone, And me warrant me make her consent to you anon. Else me give her a powder with a little drink, Wish make her sleep, and then when she noting think. With the sharp rasher me prick her by by, And stop it again and she no feel why. Please you be gone and let us too alone here: Me make her consent you no point fear.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Do it Master Doctor, and I am bound to you for aye, Ungracious girl that dost deny thy Father to obey. Look to her sir and send me word when thou hast done the deed.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Awe awe, infaith, infaith, me make her bleed.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: O wretched girl what hope remains behind, What comfort can recomfort now thy mind. Forsaken thus of Father and of friend, Why seekst thou not to bring thy life to end. Can greater woes befall unto thy share, Come Gentleman dispatch and do not spare. If it be so his pleasure and thy will, I am content my dearest blood to spill. Defer not then, hold take thine aim at me, And strike me through, for I desire to die.

sp.speaker: Bomelio,
sp.p:
The Heavens forbid, fair Maiden no not I: I am thy friend, I am no enemy.
Fear not, stand up it is only for thy sake, That I this toil and travel undertake. Thy love my Son is at my cave with me, Safe and in health long looking there for thee. Trust to my words fair maid for I am he, That overtook thee in the wood last day: And till thy coming Hermione I say. Is in my cave.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: What joyful words be these, And is Hermione your son, do then as you shall please. Behold me ready pressed to follow any way, Good father do not thus delude, a simple maid I pray. I trust unto your words, my life is in your power, And till I see Hermione, each minute is an hour.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Daughter dismay no whit but trust to me, What I have said performed thou shalt see. I have dissembled with thy Father here, The better that I might with thee confer. And since thou art so faithful to thy love, As I may well report I did thee prove. Let us be gone now closely as we may:

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Yea my good Father even when you will I pray. Thrice blessed be the hour I met with you, My Father now and Brother both adieu. Unkind to her, most kind that you should be, I leave them all my dear to come to thee.

div2.stage: Enter Hermione solus, with bookes vnder his arme.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p:
O Gods that deepest griefs are felt in closest smart, That in the smiling countenance may lurk ye wounded heart. I see the noble mind can counterfeit a bliss, When overwhelmed with a care his soul perplexed is. It is for dastard Knights that stretch on feather beds:
Despairing in adversity so low to hang their heads. The better born the more his magnanimity: The fiercer fight, the deeper wound, the more undaunted he. So I perceive it now, I well perceive it here: What I my self could not, I learn by thee my father dear. He that in golden age, I mean his lusty youth, Was thought to spend in pleasures lap, without regard of ruth. He that had lost his time as bravely as the best: Only devising how to make his joys surmount the rest. Not in that wanton youth, not in that pleasant mate: Could fortune with her fickleness his wonted mind abate. He rather challengeth to do her very worst, And makes a semblance of delight, although indeed accursed. My father thereupon devised how he might, Revenge and wreak him self on her, that wrought him such despite. And therefore I perceive he strangely useth it, Enchanting and transforming that his fancy did not fit. As I may see by these his vile blasphemous Books, My soul abhors as often as mine eye upon them looks. What gain can countervail the danger that they bring, For man to sell his soul to sin, is it not a grievous thing? To captivate his mind and all the gifts therein, to that which is of others all the most ungracious sin. Which so entangleth them that thereunto apply: As at the last forsaketh them in their extremity. Such is this art, such is the study of this skill, this supernatural devise, this Magic such it will. In ransacking his Cave, these Books I lighted on: And with his leave I will be so bold whilst he abroad is gone. To burn them all: for best that serveth for this stuff, I doubt not but at his return to please him well enough. And Gentlemen I pray, and so desire I shall, You would abhor this study, for it will confound you all.

div2.stage: Enter Lentulo with a Ring in his mouth, a Marigolde in his hand, and a faire shute of apparell on his backe: after he hath a while made some dum shew, Penulo commeth running in with two or three other.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Run for the love of God, search villains out of hand, Run I say rascals, look about ye how do you stand. The Dukes daughter is gone again, and all the Court is in an uproar: A pox on such a Physician, he shall counsel her no more.

sp.speaker: Seriant.
sp.p: See you master Penulo who is that yonder so brave,

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Cocks blood you villain what do you here you slave? 'swounds hath robbed the Duke of a shut of apparel, Why speak you not sirrah? yea will you not tell? Lay him on my masters, spare him not I say: Speak you by signs: one of you pull the Ring away.

sp.speaker: Seriant.
sp.p: Cocks blood my finger, a bites me, a pestilence there:

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: What mean ye my masters, what mean ye here.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Have you found your tongue sir, O very well, I pray you sir where had you this shut of apparel.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: This apparel, what and I stole it, what is that to thee?

sp.speaker: Penulo
sp.p: Marry sir no more but that hanged you shall be.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Then all the world shall see there is somewhat in me, When I am hanged, O I shall swing lustily. Master I shall do him great credit that hangs me, But if I may be hanged by an Attorney, I will desire thee the place to supply.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Yes marry will I for courtesy sake, Come on your way sir the pains I will take. To bring you before the Duke that he may see, What a proper man in his apparel you be.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Wilt thou faith, Master I thank thee heartily. But I must talk a little with our uplandish here, And then I will go with thee faith any where.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p:
Uplandish you rascal, where is he now,
He is gone and stole away the Dukes daughter with him too,

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: O my heart, what do you say?

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Marry that together they be both run away.

sp.speaker: Lentulo
sp.p: Nay then have after ye behind I will not stay,

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: What no such haste with you sir I pray.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: And is my Lady gone and fled, O take me up for I am dead. Farewell my Marigold, O villain Caitiff he, By bones and stones, and all the Moons, I will avenged be.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: You shall be revenged sir, that shall you presently, Away away with him to the Duke by and by.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: I can go my self and you will let me alone: Now as I walk alas I make to me my moan. When I in prison strong poor soul shall live and die: Then will I make my loving song upon mine own pigsny.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Away with him sirs why do ye tarry?

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: And thou wert in my case thou wouldst not be so hasty.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Fie upon it what a stir have we here? Never was noble man's house in such fear. Such hurring, such stirring, such running every way: Such howling, such crying, such accursing the day. That ever the villain could counterfeit so, When we least thought of it away with her to go. But the world is so full of knavery now, That we know not whom to trust I may say to you. If my wife fall sick as she may, I will make a condition, She shall never take counsel of an uplandish Physician. Hang them knaves, but what a prating keep I? When I should have been seven miles of mine errand, for why, I must go set all the Country up in a watch, If it be possible this Physician to catch.

sp.speaker: Bomelio
sp.p:
Stay daughter stay, forbear thy posting haste,
Thou needst not fear, all perils now are past. Thanks to the Gods that such success they gave, Thus happily to bring us to my cave.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: O Father still I fear mishap behind, Suspect is natural unto our kind. And perils that import a man's decay, Can never be eschewed too soon they say. Had I a sight of mine Hermione, I care not then what did become of me.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: I will herein accomplish thy desire, So grant the Gods the rest that I require. Hermione, Hermione, my Son I say, Come forth and see thy friends that for thee stay.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Welcome my Father but ten times welcome thou, The constant Lady mine that liveth now.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: And lives Hermione, lives my Hermione, What can be added more to my felicity.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Thy life my life, such comfort dost thou give,

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Happy my life, because I see thee live.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Whilst they record the sweetness of their bliss, I will apply to further as they wish. Their sweet delight by magic's cunning so, that happy they shall live in spite of foe.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: How doubtful are the let us of loyal love, Great be the dangers that true lovers prove. But when the Sun after a shower of rain, Breaks through the Clouds, and shoes his might again. More comfortable to his glory then, Because it was a while withheld of men. Peace after war is pleasanter we find, A joy differed is sweeter to the mind. So I.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p:
It hath been said, that when Vlisses was,
Ten years at Troy, and ten years more alas. Wandering abroad as chance and fortune lead, Penelope supposing him for dead. But he providing still for afterclaps, When he had scaped a thousand hard mishaps, It did him good to reckon up at last, Unto his wife his travels he had past. And sweetly then recording his distress, To make the more account of happiness. So I.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Then as the Turtle that hath found her mate, Forgets her former woes and wretched state. Renewing now her drooping heart again, Because her pleasure overcomes her pain. The same of thy desired sight I make, Whereon thy faith, thy heart and hand I take.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: And so I swear to thee unfeignedly, To live thine own, and eke thine own to die.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p:
God's blood villains, the devil is in the bed straw, 'Swounds I have been robbed, robbed, robbed, where be the thieves, my books
books did I not leave thee with my books, where are my
books, my books, where be my books villain, arrant villain.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: O father my dear father hark.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p:
Father, my dear father,
Soul give me my Books, let us have no more tarrying, the
day begins to be dark, it rains, it begins with tempests, thunder and lightning, fire and brimstone, and all my books are gone, and I cannot help my self, nor my friends, what
a pestilence who came there.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: I will tell you father if you please to hear.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p:
What canst thou tell me, tell me of a turd, what and a come
I conjure thee foul spirit down to hell, ho ho ho the devil, the
devil, a comes, a comes, a comes upon me and I lack my books.
help, help, help, lend me a Sword, a sword, O I am gone.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Alas how fell he to this madding mood,

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: The heavens and earth deny to do us good.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: O father, my good father look on me.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p:
What meant I not to shut up the door, and take the keys with me, and put the books under the bed straw, out you whore, a whore, a whore, god's blood I will dress you for a whore, I have a
cause to curse whores as long as I live, come away come away, give me my books, my books give me, give me, give.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Help, help me good Hermione.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: I come of worlds of misery. Confounded in the top of my delight, The Fates and Fortune thus against me fight.

div2.stage: Fortunes Triumph, sound Trumpets, Drummes, Cornets and Gunnes.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: See madam who can dash your bravery, Even at the pitch of your felicity. When you assure that they shall steadfast stand. Even then my power I suddenly can show, Transposing it, as it had never been so. Herein I triumph, herein I delight, Thus have I manifested now my might. Hear Ladies learn to like of Venus lure, And me love long your pleasures shall endure.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: Now thou hast done even what thou canst I see, They shall be once again relieved by me.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p:
Ye goddesses of this eternity, To whom of right belongs each earthly thing.
The King of Gods salutes ye both by me. And I beseech you mark the news I bring. My father Jupiter perceiving well, What hath herein oft been done by each of you: O how ye still endeavour to excel, Maintaining that whereon the quarrel grew. That is the government of this estate, And unto whom the sovereignty shall fall: Here therefore to conclude your long debate, Lest your contention may be counted general. Desires ye both, and so commands by me: Ye stand to his conclusion of the cause: How say you therefore will you now agree, that malice may no longer right delude.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: Brother Mercury, as I have never been, So obstinate or bent so frowardly: But that I could some time relent the ill, A woman must a little have her will. So am I now resolved for to do, What so my Father shall entreat me too.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: And all the world by me perceiveth well, Of course my fancy, my favour and my skill. And when my cause a little course hath had, I am well pleased and no longer sad.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p:
