Then thus our Father Jupiter concludes, To stay the stroke of your unceasing strife: As heretofore betwixt these lovers twain, Ye have expressed your powers upon their life. So now he wills you to withhold your hands, Enough sufficeth to confirm your might: And to conjoin ye both in friendly bands, Of faithful love wherein the Gods delight. His pleasure is, that Lady Venus you, Shall be content never to hinder them: To whom Dame Fortune shall for friendship show, Of wretched to procure them happy men,
Nor shall you Fortune once presume to take, The credit of the honour in your hand: If Lady Venus do them quite forsake, You shall not seem in her defence to stand. But whom soever one of you prefer, The other shall be subject unto her. For thus hath Jupiter determined now,

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: I must and will subscribe my will to you.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: And I most gladly thereof do allow.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: Whom Fortune favours I will not despise,

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: Whom love rejects by me shall never rise.

sp.speaker: Mercury,
sp.p: To this conclusion do you both agree?

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: For my part.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: And I most willingly.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: Then let your union be confirmed again, By proper course each one in his descent: Over mortal men and worldly things to rain, By interchange as Jupiter hath meant.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: And friendly Fortune let me entreat alone, Sith by your means these lovers hindered were: And now ye two are reconciled in one, You grant the grace their honour up to rear.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: Sweet Mercury, I give thee my consent, I will forthwith advance them to renown: And their destruction better to prevent, They shall relieve them that did throw them down.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: And I my gracious favour will bestow, Upon them all according to desert: And I will help his frenzy ere I go,

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: That Bedlam up and down he replays his part.

div2.stage: Enter Bomelio with Hermione, and Fidelia, with a Cope and Dagger.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p:
'Swounds ye here I am not for your diet, hang rascal
make a leg to me, by God's blood I will stab thee through, what
the devil the devil and all my books be gone: O most accursed
man Bomelio, go hide thyself, go hide thyself, go hang thyself, go hang. I will hang the whore out of hand, and
as for you villain, stand rascal stand.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Good Father hear me, come take a little rest, Yea my sweet Father come sleep upon my breast.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Hark ye whore, see what an impudent whore it is, sleep you whore I will sleep with you anon, god's blood you whore, I will hang you up,

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Help help Hermione.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Good father let her alone, come let us go,

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: Now with my music I will recure his woe.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p:
Hark hark my hearts, Pipes, Fiddles, O brave, I shall
have my books again, dance about, Robin Hood is a good
knave, come besse let us go sleep, come besse together together

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: Now will I charm him that he shall not wake, Until he be relieved in this place: Then take her blood and cast it on this brake. And therewithal besprinkle all his face. And he shall be restored to his sense, His health and memory as heretofore: Do this for I must now depart from hence, And so your sorrows shall increase no more.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Fidelia, what hast thou heard my dear, O comfortable words were they but true: If any God or Goddess be so near, Vouchsafe of pity on our pains to rue. Delude not with a fained fantasy: The wretched mind of men in misery.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Alas Hermione, let us not feed And flatter our selves with my good surmise: We are too much accursed so to speed, Or any hope thereof for to devise. Resolve your self dear friend another way, And let us never look for happy day.

div2.stage: Enter Phizantius, Armenio, Penulo, and Lentulo.

sp.speaker: Phyzan.
sp.p: When thirst of hot revenge inflameth high desire, When malice blindeth so the minds of them that would aspire. That to enlarge their names, they wreak not his despite, That overseeth all their works, their doings to requite. Mark then what followeth when Princes ye provoke, The deeper and the larger wound when longest is the stroke. And this hath moved me to leave my Court a while, To be content in sweat of brows, in trouble pain and toil. To seek out wretches them that have abused me so, And to reward their villainy according ere we go.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: May it please your honour it is excellent done, God's blood if I were a Prince and had such an noble Son. That should be so highly abused as he hath been, Would I put it up? no by his wounds I would never lin. Till I had made such a mingle mangle upon their nose, That their skin should serve to make me a doublet and a pair of hose.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: What you would not? Ifaith you look not with the face, When you have their skin sir, what will you do with the case? But master Prince, since you are come to this trauelation, I will bring you to mine old masters convoculation. Where he hides him self when I ran away: Its not far within these woods: how think you sir I pray?

sp.speaker: Phyzan.
sp.p: Lead on the way and I will follow thee,

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Why then come on my valiant hearts, march on and follow me. But I will make this bargain first, hear you me what I say? When I come home you shall not let my master beat me for running away.

sp.speaker: Phyzan.
sp.p: He shall not I warrant thee:

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p:
Why then my noble youths of Oak pluck up your hearts with me. Will you come sir, come on Ifaith keep in order you thereby:
We shall find her Ifaith master Prince anon I know. And then I will trounce him for running away with an other man's wife I trow.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Stand sir, who lies a sunning yonder can you tell?

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Its a Beggar with a Rogue.

sp.speaker: Phyzan.
sp.p: It is my daughter I see full well.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Fidelia be content, shrink not at all,

sp.speaker: Phyzan.
sp.p: Strike not a stroke my son.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: For help I shall go run and call.

sp.speaker: Phyzan.
sp.p: And art thou found false traitor and untrue: Traitor to him that dealt so well with thee: Did I devise to stop that would ensue, And found my cares such issue as I see. I see I am abused too too much, And too much sufferance is cause of this abuse, This high abuse of yours as being such, Affords no cloak nor colour of excuse. O where is thankfulness and love become? Where is fear of Princes wrath exiled? Even this is the unhappiness of some, To be of them they trusted most beguiled, But sometime pardon breeds a second ill: Thou shameless wench, and thou false hearted knight, By your unhappy deeds I learn this skill. But yet I list not kill thee as I might, Her will I have and keep her as I may, On pain of death I charge thee hence away.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p:
O Prince, this sentence hath his force and strength, And dead I am that here appear to live: For how alas can this my life have length, When she is hence that life and sense doth give. But since alas I must be only he, Whom Fortune vows to make a common game: Armenio my foe do this for me, With thy revenge to end my open shame. To help thee to digest thine injury,
Appease thee with Hermiones tragedy.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Far be the thought of that accursed deed, O sweet Hermione my sweet Hermione: Foul be his fall that makes thy body bleed, O sweet Hermione my sweet Hermione. And father this I vow, forgive it me, I will be sacrifice for this offence: And or I will have my Hermione, My chosen love: or never part from hence. Him have the destinies ordained mine: Most worthy, me your daughter every way: Nor he to any will his choice resign. No more my troubled thoughts will let me say.

sp.speaker: Phyzan.
sp.p: What wilt thou foolish girl and obstinate, Sayst thou this treason is devised by fate. That shall we try, dispatch her hence away, Let us see who dares our princely will gainsay.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Sir, and you will have us carry her, here be them come of the carriers:

sp.speaker: Lentulo
sp.p: And you will have us marry her, here be them come of the marriers.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Lord I marvel to whose share this Lady will fall, I am sure my part in her will be least of all.

div2.stage: Venus and Fortune shew themselues and speak to Phizantius, while Hermione standeth in a maze.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: High time it is that now we did appear, If we desire to end their misery:

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: Phizantius stay, and unto us give ear, What thou determinest performed cannot be.

sp.speaker: Phyzan.
sp.p: Dread goddess, whatsoever of this place, If I herein have disobeyed thy grace. Of favour grant for to remit the same, Let me not suffer undeserved blame.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p:
Phizantius stand up be of good cheer, None but thy friends are met together here. Thy friends though goddesses in other things,
Yet interchange an alteration brings. And now whereas you seek in what you can, To let your child to marry with this man. Know that it is the pleasure of our will, That they together be conjoined still. For It is not so, he is not born so base, As you esteem, but of a noble race. His Father is the good Bomelio, That sleepeth here oppressed with woe. Whom Phalaris thy father on a false report, In wrath and anger banished his Court. But this is he to whom thou wishest oft good, And this his Son born of a noble blood. Think it no scorn to thee or thine hereafter, To have his Son espoused to thy daughter.

sp.speaker: Phyzan,
sp.p: Right gracious Goddess if this be true indeed, As I believe, because from you it doth proceed. Then pardon me, for had I known it so, His Son had never tasted of this woe. Unwitting of his linage till this time, But I presumed sprung of a noble line. But hence and please your deities my grief, Because my Son is dumb without relief.

sp.speaker: Penulo.
sp.p: Ifaith sirrah thou and I may hold our peace with their leave, For none but wise men speak here I perceive.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: In some respects so, in some respects not, For a fools bolt is soon enough shot.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: Phizantius fear no longer his distress, The gracious Gods provide for his redress. The shedding of thy daughters dearest blood, Shall both to him and to this man do good. For let this Fern be dipped in many a place, And as he sleepeth cast it in his face. And let his tongue be washed there withal, And both of them relieved see you shall.

sp.speaker: Phizan.
sp.p: How say you daughter will you grant thereto,

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: Most willing sir if you vouchsafe to do. But this request which I most humbly pray, Then I may be Hermiones for aye.

sp.speaker: Phyzan.
sp.p: With all my heart hereon I give my hand.

sp.speaker: Fidelia.
sp.p: I take it sir, and to your word I stand. And for thy sake Hermione my dear, See what I do, although it touch me near. Now take thy fill and for his madness prove,

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: O sweet and fearful sight the sign of love.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: If it be any sweeter masters that runs from you so. I pray you give me some of your blessings ere you go.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: I strive to speak and glad I find my speech, Forgive Hermione, forgive me I beseech. And you good sister pardon my friends too, Too rash in all I ventured to do. See what proceedeth from unstable youth, Shame to him self, and to his friends a cause of ruth.

sp.speaker: Hermione.
sp.p: Armenio long hath my end desired, To hear the proffer of this pleasant peace: Which sith the Gods do grant as we require, Henceforth let rancour and contention cease. And in our breast be knit forever sure, The links of love perpetual to endure.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: What have I heard? what is it that they say? Amazed quite, confounded every way, My son Hermione, I know that is the same, And that is my Prince, now comes grief and shame.

sp.speaker: Phizan.
sp.p: My Lord Bomelio shun not, I know you now, Forgive the fact my Father did to you. And what he did impute it not to me, Thy former place I will restore to thee, In token of our faithful amity, We will be joined in near affinity.

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p:
Long live Phizantius, long live in happy ease, The Gods be blessed I live this day to see: What please the one shall never me displease.
Thrice happy now for all my misery.

sp.speaker: Penulo
sp.p: Why then sir, sith every thing is come to so good an end, I hope my good master you will stand my good friend. And give me but two or three thousand pound a year to live on.

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Much in my nock Nicols you and I shall slave it anon.

sp.speaker: Armenio.
sp.p: Assure thee Penulo thou shalt not want as long as I live,

sp.speaker: Lentulo.
sp.p: Why then master, mine old Master, I pray you forgive, Your old runaway, it was for fashion sake, I will do so no more

sp.speaker: Bomelio.
sp.p: Look you do not sirrah and then I pardon you therefore.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.p: Thus every thing united is by love, Now Gods and men are reconciled again: On whom because I did my pleasure prove, I will reward you for your former pain. Receive the favours of our deity, And sing the praise of Venus sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.p: And for I played my part with Lady love, While each did strive for chief authority: Your good deserts dame Fortune so doth move, To give these signs of liberality. Thus for amends of this your late unrest, By Love and Fortune ye shall all be blessed. And thus hereof this inward care I have, That wisdom ruleth love and Fortune both: Though riches fail and beauty seem to save, Yet wisdom forward still unconquered goeth. This we beseech you take friendly in worth. And sith by love and fortune our troubles all do cease, God save her Majesty that keeps us all in peace. Now they and we do all triumph in joy, And love and fortune are linked sure friends: All grief is fled for your annoy. Fortune and love makes all amends. Let us rejoice then for the same, And sing high praises of their name.
